settings.studentLoanInterestDeductible: Student loan interest is tax deductible
settings.countryRuleExplanation: These rules affect how your loans are taxed and can impact your loan payoff strategy. Different countries have different tax benefits for various types of loans.
settings.updateCurrencyToCountryDefault: Would you like to update your currency to {currency} to match your selected country?
settings.updateLanguageToCountryDefault: Would you like to update your language preference to match your selected country?

wealthOptimizer.ourApproachDescription: We compare what happens if you invest for the exact same time it would take to pay off the loan with extra payments.
wealthOptimizer.riskAdjustmentDescription: We use a {factor}% risk adjustment factor to account for market volatility. This means an expected market return of {expectedReturn}% is adjusted to {adjustedReturn}% when comparing with the guaranteed return from debt paydown.
wealthOptimizer.fairComparisonTitle: Understanding fair comparisons: Invest vs. Pay Down Debt
wealthOptimizer.fairComparisonExplanation: To make a fair comparison between paying extra on a loan versus investing, we need to compare over the same time period. Many online calculators and articles make the mistake of comparing incompatible timeframes.
wealthOptimizer.commonMistakeDescription: Comparing investing for 30 years with paying off a loan in 8 years. This isn't fair because the timeframes are different.
wealthOptimizer.ourApprochDescription: We compare what happens if you invest for the exact same time it would take to pay off the loan with extra payments.
wealthOptimizer.fairComparisonConclusion: Our analysis shows you exactly how much you'll save or earn over the same time period, making it a truly fair, apples-to-apples comparison.
wealthOptimizer.selectLoans: Select Loans to Include in Analysis
wealthOptimizer.monthlyMoneyAvailable: Monthly money available for extra payments & investing
wealthOptimizer.totalBudgetHelp: This is your total monthly budget for debt payments and investing, including minimum payments.
wealthOptimizer.extraMoneyHelp: This is extra money available after accounting for your minimum loan payments.
wealthOptimizer.totalBudgetInfo: Analysis will consider your total budget of {totalBudget}/month, including minimum payments.
wealthOptimizer.extraBudgetInfo: Analysis will consider your extra {extraMoney}/month plus minimum payments of {minimumPayments}/month.
wealthOptimizer.basedOnInputs: Based on your inputs, we've analyzed different strategies over {years} years to maximize your wealth.
wealthOptimizer.title: Optimize Your Extra Money: Loan Paydown vs. Investment
wealthOptimizer.description: This premium tool helps you decide whether to use extra money to pay down debt or invest in the stock market.
wealthOptimizer.selectLoansToInclude: Select Loans to Include in Analysis
wealthOptimizer.noLoansYet: No loans found in this category. Add a loan to get started.
wealthOptimizer.totalMonthlyBudget: Total monthly budget for debt & investing
wealthOptimizer.monthlyExtraMoney: Monthly money available for extra payments & investing
wealthOptimizer.totalBudgetTooltip: This is your total monthly budget for debt payments and investing, including minimum payments.
wealthOptimizer.extraMoneyTooltip: This is extra money available after accounting for your minimum loan payments.
wealthOptimizer.totalBudgetDescription: This includes all loan payments (minimum: {minimum}/month) plus any extra for additional payments or investing.
wealthOptimizer.extraMoneyDescription: This is money available after paying for essentials (housing, food, utilities, etc.) that can be used for extra debt payments or investing.
wealthOptimizer.analysisTotalBudget: Analysis will consider your total budget of {amount}/month, including minimum payments.
wealthOptimizer.analysisExtraMoney: Analysis will consider your extra {extra}/month plus minimum payments of {minimum}/month.
wealthOptimizer.selectAtLeastOneLoan: Please select at least one loan
wealthOptimizer.errorCalculatingResults: Error calculating results. Please check your inputs.
wealthOptimizer.analysisDescription: Based on your inputs, we've analyzed different strategies over {years} years to maximize your wealth.
wealthOptimizer.premiumFeature: WealthOptimizer™ is a premium Penvid feature
wealthOptimizer.noLoansToCompare: No loans to compare. Please select at least one loan and try again.
wealthOptimizer.breakdownExplanation: This breakdown shows exactly what happens if you put your extra money toward each loan vs. investing it
wealthOptimizer.projectionNote: These projections use a {rate}% inflation-adjusted annual return for S&P 500 investments (historical average from 1928 to 2024).
wealthOptimizer.marketReturnsNote: Actual market returns may vary significantly over time. Past performance is not indicative of future results.
wealthOptimizer.analysisAssumptionsNote: The analysis assumes consistent monthly contributions and doesn't account for taxes on investment gains or interest tax deductions.
wealthOptimizer.customApproachNote: Your specific loan terms, income, and financial goals may require a customized approach.
wealthOptimizer.payDownLoanFirst: Pay down this loan first! You'll save {amount} more than investing.
wealthOptimizer.minimumPaymentsOnly: Minimum payments only! Investing will save you {amount} more than paying this loan early.
wealthOptimizer.loanRateHigher: This loan's {loanRate}% interest rate is higher than the expected {investRate}% return from investing.
wealthOptimizer.loanRateLower: This loan's {loanRate}% interest rate is lower than the expected {investRate}% return from investing.
wealthOptimizer.interestSavingsExceed: The interest savings from paying this loan off early exceed what you'd earn by investing.
wealthOptimizer.earnMoreByInvesting: You'll earn more by investing than you'll save by paying this loan off early.
wealthOptimizer.compareImpact: We compare the total financial impact of two strategies for each loan
wealthOptimizer.strategy1Description: Pay minimum payment and invest the extra money at an expected {rate}% annual return
wealthOptimizer.strategy2Description: Put all your extra money toward paying down the loan faster
wealthOptimizer.forHighInterestLoans: For high-interest loans (above {rate}%), the interest you save by paying off early typically exceeds what you'd earn by investing.
wealthOptimizer.forLowInterestLoans: For low-interest loans (below {rate}%), you typically earn more by investing the money than you save in interest.
wealthOptimizer.sixPercentRule: Note: This analysis follows the "6% rule" highlighted by major financial institutions, which suggests prioritizing debt repayment for loans with interest rates above 6% while investing for loans with lower rates.
wealthOptimizer.addLoanDescription: Add a new loan to include in your wealth optimization analysis

strategyDescriptions.minimumPaymentsInvest: Pay only the minimum required payments on all loans and invest the rest in the S&P 500.
strategyDescriptions.debtAvalanche: Pay minimum on all loans, but put any extra money toward the highest interest loan first. Once paid off, move to the next highest interest loan. Invest only after all loans are paid off.
strategyDescriptions.hybridApproach: Pay off only loans with interest rates higher than the S&P 500's inflation-adjusted return ({rate}%), and invest the rest.
strategyDescriptions.aggressivePaydown: Aggressively pay down all loans for the first 5 years (focusing on high-interest loans first), then switch to investing all extra money after that.

strategyResults.riskAdjustedValue: Risk-adjusted value based on current scenario
strategyResults.projectionNote: These projections use a {rate}% inflation-adjusted annual return for S&P 500 investments (historical average from 1928 to 2024).
strategyResults.marketReturnsNote: Actual market returns may vary significantly over time. Past performance is not indicative of future results.
strategyResults.consistentContributionsNote: The analysis assumes consistent monthly contributions and doesn't account for taxes on investment gains or interest tax deductions.
strategyResults.customizedApproachNote: Your specific loan terms, income, and financial goals may require a customized approach.
strategyResults.riskConsiderationNote: Consider your personal risk tolerance when deciding between debt paydown and investment strategies.
strategyResults.riskExplanation: Choose a perspective to see how different market outcomes could affect your financial future. This helps you understand the risks and trade-offs between different strategies.
strategyResults.pessimisticDescription: Assumes investments perform worse than expected, with returns about 40% lower than historical averages. This is a more conservative view.
strategyResults.standardDescription: Uses historical average returns with a realistic 30% underperformance risk adjustment. This is a balanced view.
strategyResults.optimisticDescription: Assumes investments perform close to or better than historical averages. This is a more aggressive view.
strategyResults.riskAnalysisDescription: See how the recommended strategy performs under different market conditions to help make a more informed decision.
strategyResults.pessimisticScenarioDesc: If markets underperform historical averages by ~40%
strategyResults.optimisticScenarioDesc: If markets perform at or above historical averages
strategyResults.whatThisMeans: What This Means For Your Strategy
strategyResults.whatThisMeansDesc: Understanding these different scenarios can help you choose a strategy that aligns with your risk tolerance and financial goals. A more conservative investor might prioritize debt reduction to ensure a guaranteed return.
strategyResults.marketVolatility: Market volatility and potential downturns could affect investment returns
strategyResults.inflationRisk: Inflation may reduce the real value of your investments over time
strategyResults.jobLossRisk: Income disruption could impact your ability to make consistent payments
strategyResults.interestRateChanges: Interest rate changes might affect variable-rate loans and investment returns

loanComparison.fairComparisonDescription: We provide two comparison methods to help you make a more informed decision. The short-term comparison shows what happens during the accelerated payoff period, while the long-term comparison shows what happens over the full regular loan term.
loanComparison.shortTermDescription: Compares paying extra on this loan vs investing that money for the same time period it would take to pay off the loan with extra payments.
loanComparison.fullTermDescription: Compares the total outcome after the original {years}-year loan term for both strategies.
loanComparison.fairComparisonNote: The short-term comparison is the fairest direct comparison, but the long-term comparison shows the full potential of each strategy over time. Your personal time horizon should influence which metric you prioritize.
loanComparison.breakdown: This breakdown shows exactly what happens if you put your extra money toward each loan vs. investing it
loanComparison.riskAdjustedExplanation: Market returns of {spReturn}% are risk-adjusted to {riskAdjustedReturn}% to account for volatility and uncertainty. This helps create more realistic comparisons between guaranteed loan interest savings and potential investment returns.
loanComparison.highInterestLoanStrategy: High interest loans (above {threshold}%) - Definitely pay down first
loanComparison.mediumInterestLoanStrategy: Medium interest loans ({lower}% to {upper}%) - Consider risk tolerance
loanComparison.lowInterestLoanStrategy: Low interest loans (below {threshold}%) - Probably invest instead
loanComparison.definitelyPayDownDesc: This loan's interest rate is significantly higher than market returns. Paying it down provides a guaranteed return that outperforms investing.
loanComparison.probablyPayDownDesc: This loan's {loanRate}% rate is between the market return ({spReturn}%) and risk-adjusted return ({riskAdjustedReturn}%). Consider your risk tolerance - more conservative investors should pay it down.
loanComparison.investInsteadDesc: This loan's {loanRate}% rate is below the risk-adjusted market return of {riskAdjustedReturn}%. Even accounting for risk, investing is likely more profitable.
loanComparison.payDownThisLoanMessage: Pay down this loan first! You'll save {amount} more than investing.
loanComparison.minimumPaymentsMessage: Minimum payments only! Investing will save you {amount} more than paying this loan early.
loanComparison.highInterestLoanInsight: This loan's {loanRate}% interest rate is significantly higher than the expected {spReturn}% market return. Paying down this loan is the safer choice with a guaranteed return.
loanComparison.mediumInterestLoanInsight: This loan's {loanRate}% rate is between the market return ({spReturn}%) and risk-adjusted return ({riskAdjustedReturn}%). Your risk tolerance should determine your approach.
loanComparison.lowInterestLoanInsight: This loan's {loanRate}% rate is below the risk-adjusted market return of {riskAdjustedReturn}%. Even with conservative assumptions, investing is likely more profitable.
loanComparison.compareImpact: We compare the total financial impact of three approaches for each loan:
loanComparison.strategy1Description: Pay minimum payment and invest the extra money at an expected {returnRate}% annual return
loanComparison.strategy2Description: Put all your extra money toward paying down the loan faster
loanComparison.riskAdjustedStrategyDescription: Account for market uncertainty by assuming only {riskFactor}% of the {marketReturn}% expected return, resulting in a risk-adjusted return of {riskAdjustedReturn}%
loanComparison.highInterestLoansExplanation: For high-interest loans (above {returnRate}%), the interest you save by paying off early typically exceeds what you'd earn by investing.
loanComparison.lowInterestLoansExplanation: For low-interest loans (below {returnRate}%), you typically earn more by investing the money than you save in interest.
loanComparison.ruleNote: Note: This analysis follows the "risk-adjusted return" approach, which considers both the mathematical and psychological aspects of debt paydown vs. investing.
loanComparison.ourRecommendation: Our Tiered Approach to Loan Payoff vs. Investing
loanComparison.tieredStrategyExplanation: For the most optimal balance of guaranteed returns and growth potential, we recommend this prioritization strategy:
loanComparison.tier1: Tier 1: Pay down loans with rates above {threshold}% first, regardless of market conditions
loanComparison.tier2: Tier 2: For loans with rates between {lower}% and {upper}%, consider your risk tolerance - conservative investors should pay them off
loanComparison.tier3: Tier 3: For loans with rates between {lower}% and {upper}%, minimum payments are generally better, but weigh psychological benefits of being debt-free
loanComparison.tier4: Tier 4: For very low-interest loans (below {threshold}%), almost always pay just the minimum and invest the difference
loanComparison.balanceExplanation: Remember that paying down debt offers a guaranteed return equal to the interest rate, while investing provides a potentially higher but uncertain return. Your decision should reflect your personal comfort with financial risk.

US.description: United States tax and financial rules

taxInfo.title: Tax Insights
taxInfo.description: Country-specific tax rules and savings opportunities
taxInfo.tryAgain: Please try again later or refresh the page.
taxInfo.loginPrompt: Sign in to see tax insights
taxInfo.loginRequired: You need to be logged in to view tax optimization recommendations for this loan.
taxInfo.mortgageDeductionExplanation: In {country}, mortgage interest is tax-deductible at a rate of approximately {rate}.
taxInfo.mortgageDeductionCap: The deduction is limited to loan amounts up to {cap}.
taxInfo.studentDeductionExplanation: In {country}, student loan interest may be eligible for tax deductions.
taxInfo.studentDeductionCap: You can deduct up to {cap} per year from your taxable income.
taxInfo.otherLoanExplanation: In {country}, {loanType} interest is typically treated differently than mortgage interest for tax purposes.
taxInfo.optimizationDescription: Based on your country's tax rules, here are some optimization strategies to consider:
taxInfo.disclaimer: Tax rules change frequently. Consult a tax professional for personalized advice.
taxInfo.unexpectedError: An unexpected error occurred while loading tax information.
taxInfo.dataSourceNote: Tax data updated for 2025 fiscal year
taxInfo.mortgageExplanation: In {country}, mortgage interest is tax-deductible at a rate of approximately {rate}. This means you get back about {rate} of your interest payments as tax savings.
taxInfo.studentLoanExplanation: In {country}, student loan interest may be eligible for tax deductions. These are typically calculated automatically in your annual tax return.
taxInfo.deductibleLoanExplanation: In {country}, {loanType} interest is also tax-deductible at approximately {rate}. Interest expenses to banks should be automatically reported to the tax authorities.
taxInfo.nonDeductibleLoanExplanation: In {country}, {loanType} interest is typically not tax-deductible in the same way as mortgage interest.
taxInfo.mortgageBondExplanation: In {country}, mortgage bond (realkreditlån) interest is tax-deductible at approximately {rate}. This is the traditional Danish mortgage type with advantageous terms.
taxInfo.homeLoanExplanation: In {country}, home loan (boliglån) interest from banks is also tax-deductible at approximately {rate}, even though they're not mortgage bonds.
